explanation: Agent A is correct. The statement "(void) used;" is an executed expression statement with no side effects; removing it does not change the run‑time behaviour of the program. Under the Rule 2.2 definition — "Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code" — this is dead code. The presence of mhd_assert earlier explains the situation: when asserts are compiled out, "used" becomes otherwise unused and the only remaining reference is the void cast, which is a no‑op at run time. (Note: this is a common idiom to suppress compiler warnings and can be addressed by a documented deviation or by alternative approaches, but strictly speaking it violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2.)
